title-group.article-title: The Post-Communist State: In Search of a Paradigm

abstract.p: Author present external (globalisation) and internal (post-communist mode of capital formation based on commercialization of State's functions) causes for the decline of the "traditional" modern State based on unified, hierarchically organized procedural rationality. Two strategies aimed at overcoming the systemic weakness of the post-communist state are presented as well. One strategy is a military form of State without militaristic content (as in Putin's Russia). The other strategy is a mastery of a meta-regulation able to coordinate and integrate subsystems, each based on a different logic. The latter approach is used in contemporary China and rooted in the deep layers of the traditional Chinese culture. Author underlines the dilemmas of "post--democratic" state that develops in post-communism, with its decentration, growing irrelevance of democratic institutions and de-policization of decision making characteristic of technocratic, commercialized, network state. More on these problems see in the Author's Post-Communism. The Emerging Enigma. Warszawa: Institute of Political Studies, 1999.
